channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Vladimir Putin Denounces U.S. Over FIFA Arrests
item.description: The Russian president denounced what he said was “another blatant attempt by the United States to extend its jurisdiction to other states.”
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR and ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Another Huge Statue in Russia? Not Rare, but Hugely Divisive
item.description: Plans for an 82-foot-tall statue in Moscow honoring the nation’s patron saint, St. Vladimir, have exposed a fierce contest over faith and identity.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The sculptor Salavat Scherbakov worked on a model of the statue of St. Vladimir, Russia’s patron saint, in his studio. The final work is to stand 82 feet tall on a hill in Moscow, but some Muscovites are unhappy about the plans.

item.title: Arrests Overshadow Palestinians’ Bid to Oust Israel From FIFA
item.description: A vote on the issue is scheduled for Friday, and both sides say they are struggling to get their messages across to other delegations.
item.dc:creator: SAM BORDEN and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: H.I.V. Treatment Should Start at Diagnosis, U.S. Health Officials Say
item.description: Federal health officials announced the new guidelines after a clinical trial showed pronounced benefits for people put on antiretroviral drugs as soon as they learned they were infected.
item.category: National Institute for Allergy and Infectious Disease
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: Pills were prepared for H.I.V. patients in Thailand in February. A study found early treatment for people with H.I.V. cut down on the number of deaths.

item.title: Cameron Presses E.U. for ‘Better Deal for Britain’
item.description: The British prime minister, on a trip to Europe, is warning that Britain may leave the European Union if it cannot win policy changes.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Putin Declares Soldiers’ Deaths and Wounds Secret, in War and Peace
item.description: Political opponents insisted that President Vladimir V. Putin’s latest decree was the result of Russian troops’ clandestine involvement in Ukraine fighting.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Robert S. Wistrich, Scholar of Anti-Semitism, Dies at 70
item.description: The professor at Hebrew University in Jerusalem was the author or editor of 29 books, including the encyclopedic “Antisemitism: The Longest Hatred.”
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: After Indicting 14 Soccer Officials, U.S. Vows to End Graft in FIFA
item.description: Hours after indicting 14 people, the Justice Department and prosecutors for the Eastern District of New York pledged to rid the international soccer organization of systemic corruption.
item.dc:creator: STEPHANIE CLIFFORD and MATT APUZZO
item.media:credit: Pascal Mora for The New York Times
item.media:description: Walter De Gregorio, FIFA’s chief communication officer, during a news conference Wednesday at the organization’s headquarters to respond to the indictments.

item.title: Dalai Lama Urges Aung San Suu Kyi to Help Myanmar’s Rohingya
item.description: The Dalai Lama criticized the leader of Myanmar’s democracy movement for not addressing the country’s harsh treatment of its Rohingya minority.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rohingya refugees cooked food at a shelter in Indonesia on Thursday. Thousands have fled Myanmar to escape deprivation and persecution.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Art and Hypocrisy in the Gulf
item.description: Abu Dhabi is opening cultural centers, but is barring artists and writers from entering.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS MCGEEHAN

item.title: Sepp Blatter Says FIFA Must Police Itself
item.description: The scandal has not changed the strange electoral math of FIFA. Europe’s support of Prince Ali bin al-Hussein is outweighed by support of many small countries for Blatter.
item.dc:creator: SAM BORDEN, ANDREW DAS and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: "We, or I, cannot monitor everyone all of the time. If people want to do wrong, they will also try to hide it," Sepp Blatter told FIFA's annual congress.

item.title: Chemical Weapon Stockpiles Greatly Reduced, Treaty Group Reports
item.description: The Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons said the achievement was “a major milestone” toward eradicating the weapons.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Letter From Europe: British Inquiries Shed Light, Until They Don't
item.description: The Iraq war investigation is one of a series that the authorities use to airbrush official errors or at least to delay embarrassment.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Burundi’s Catholic Church Withdraws Support for Elections
item.description: The church said it would withdraw its priests appointed to help organize elections next month that are at the heart of the country’s upheaval.
item.dc:creator: SADI NIYUNGEKO

item.title: Women in Tunisia Tell of Decades of Police Cruelty, Violence and Rape
item.description: In an Arab country where women’s rights had made advances, women are testifying about abuses under two dictatorships.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hamida Ajengui was just 21 when she was arrested by Tunisia’s state police, who beat her, hurled abuse at her and threatened her with rape.

item.title: Sunnis Fleeing ISIS Find Few Doors Open Elsewhere in Iraq
item.description: Many Iraqi Shiites are looking with distrust at Sunni civilians displaced by attacks by Sunni militants in the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Iraqi civilians fleeing fighting in Ramadi crossed the Bzebiz Bridge, which offers passage into Baghdad from Anbar Province.

item.title: Hospitalized Opposition Activist Needs Treatment Outside Russia, Wife Says
item.description: Vladimir Kara-Murza, who collapsed and lost consciousness on Tuesday in mysterious circumstances, is the federal coordinator of the civic group Open Russia.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: FIFA Should Give Israel the Red Card
item.description: Soccer is my life, but players like me are punished for being Palestinian.
item.dc:creator: IYAD ABU GHARQOUD

item.title: Arrest Opens Window on China’s Role in Designer Drug Market
item.description: A major manufacturer of “spice,” a lethal synthetic, shows the trouble a country with a large, poorly regulated pharmaceutical sector can bring.
item.dc:creator: ALAN SCHWARZ
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Empty packets of synthetic marijuana, or “spice,” at a Drug Enforcement Administration laboratory in Dulles, Va.

item.title: Other Foreigners Detained in Iran
item.description: In the past seven years, several journalists and American travelers have been arrested in Iran for spying. All have denied the accusations.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:credit: Robin Marchant/Getty Images; Vahid Salemi/Associated Press; Freeamir.org
item.media:description: From left: Maziar Bahari, Reza Taghavi and Amir Hekmati.
